instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 4v
threads.message:
Hi, i am new here.
Long story short, was banging my head around <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a board.
Originally came in with no backlight. Opened, of course water damage. Replaced water damaged area ( U770, <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>), started to work.
Noticed that there are some water marks around SMC, cleaned, reflowed. Also corrosion around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, cleaned it up, trace disappeared from c7121to <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR>, ran a wire, made sure there is no short. Connected my charger from DC power supply, was taking 2,4amps, fan spins, backlight on all good, customer collected.

After week customer calls back in, saying it is not charging, i try my power supply, it is charging, try customers charger, it is not, so all blame on charger.
After a week customer comes in with new charger, still not charging, but charging fine from my DC power supply.
I tested customers charger on another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and it is working fine.
So i decided to check around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, all voltages are present. So decided to swap <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, and there problems begun. I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, got 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, decided that either soldering is not good or ic is faulty, so replaced one more, this time inspecting closely all pins under microscope, soldering was decent, still same 4v. replaced once more with 3rd ic, same 4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 4V, Here are the measurements:

Green light/Orange light Present

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42V

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Pin1 0v
Pin2 14v
Pin3 3.8v
Pin4 2.53v
Pin5 2.35v
Pin6 0v
Pin7 2.68v
Pin8 0.58v
Pin9 0.01v
Pin10 3.36v
Pin11 3.32v
Pin12 3.38v
Pin13 3.08v
Pin14 3.08v
Pin15 0.04v
Pin16 3.8v
Pin17 3.9v
Pin18 3.9v
Pin19 5.05v
Pin20 5.03v
Pin21 0.02v
Pin22 0v
Pin23 3.93v
Pin24 4.86v
Pin25 4.74v
Pin26 12.68v
Pin27 14.4v
Pin28 14.46v

Resistance between pins 17/18 = 3.2ohm
Resistance between pins 27/28 = 20.3ohm

All resistors around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> looks good and i also measured them agains schematic, they are ok.

Any help will be much appreciated. Thanks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 4v
threads.message:
Check <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and its traces.
If good, replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.
Inspect for corrosion all around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 4v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 60626, member: 682"]
Check <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and its traces.
If good, replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.
Inspect for corrosion all around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>...
[/QUOTE]
Thanks, solved it.
was digging around <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>, everything looked well. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, was no joy. Decided just in case to replace <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>(it was not shorted) and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> returned.
Can mark as solved.

threads.message:
